revision.text:
{{disputed|date=July 2015}}
{{grading}} In [[South Africa]], the grading system used in secondary schools until 2008 (when the education minister implemented [[Outcomes Based Education]] or OBE curriculum) was as follows:
*Code 7 (A Symbol): 80 - 100% *Code 6 (B Symbol): 70 - 79% *Code 5 (C Symbol): 60 - 69% *Code 4 (D Symbol): 50 - 59% *Code 3 (E Symbol): 40 - 49% *Code 2 (F Symbol): 30 - 39% *Code 1 (FF Symbol): 0 - 29%
The OBE system, when in its experimental stages, originally used a scale from 1 - 4 (a pass being a 3 and a '1st class pass' being above 70%), but this system was considered far too coarse and replaced by a scale from 1 to 7.
For the final standard exams, a 'normal pass' is given for an average mark 50%-59%, and a distinction is given for an average of 80% or more.
Most universities follow a model based on the British system. Thus, at the University of Cape Town and the University of South Africa (UNISA), the percentages are calibrated as follows: a 1st class pass is given for 75% and above, a second (division one) for 70 - 74%, a second (division two) for 60%-69%, and a third for 50 - 59%. Any lower than 40% is a fail. The University of the Witwatersrand considers an A to be 75% and above.
==Sources== * South African Education Department [https://web.archive.org/web/20100331073634/http://www.education.gov.za/emis/emisweb/07stats/Education%20Statistics%20in%20South%20Africa%202007.pdf] * Stellenbosch University Grade Comparison (page 21) [https://web.archive.org/web/20101215174638/http://www0.sun.ac.za/international/assets/forms/Living_in_Stellenbosch_2010.pdf] * Cape Town University Academic Grading [https://web.archive.org/web/20090429052200/http://www.uct.ac.za/apply/intlapplicants/semester/overview/credit]
{{Africa topic|Academic grading in}}
[[Category:Academic grading by country|South Africa]] [[Category:Education in South Africa|Grading]] [[Category:Academia in South Africa|Grading]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = Actors Comedy Studio |image = |caption = |leader_title = Gunnar Rohrbacher |leader_name = |leader_title2 = Lauren Bertoni |leader_name2 = |membership = |headquarters = [[Los Angeles, CA]] |formation = January 17, 2011 |type = [[Sitcom]] |predecessor = |budget= |purpose= |region_served = [[International]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |motto = We take comedy seriously |website = [http://www.actorscomedystudio.com actorscomedystudio.com] }}
'''Actors Comedy Studio''' is a [[sitcom]] and [[audition]] technique acting school in [[Los Angeles, California]]. The school was founded in 2011 by [[Gunnar Todd Rohrbacher]] and Lauren Bertoni. The program primarily focuses on acting for sitcoms and audition technique.
==Class Format== Actors Comedy Studio was created as a counterpoint to the [[improvisational]] and [[sketch comedy]] training that has "proliferated massively in Los Angeles."<ref>Strassberg, Rebecca. "1 Thing Every Aspiring Sitcom Actor Must Know." ''Backstage West''. Backstage West, 21 Oct. 2014. Web. 30 Apr. 2015. <http://www.backstage.com/advice-for-actors/inside-job/1-thing-every-aspiring-sitcom-actor-must-know/>.</ref> The program consists of three primary courses: Acting for Sitcoms, Sitcom Essentials and Sitcom Master Class. Acting for Sitcoms introduces new students to cold reading, script analysis, character development and audition technique. Sitcom Essentials focuses on script analysis, [[multi-cam]] vs. [[single-camera]] audition technique, [[Read-through|table read]], [[rehearsal]]s, camera blocking, and shooting scenes in front of a live [[studio audience]]. The Sitcom Master Class is specifically designed for working actors. Admittance into the Master Class is achieved by one of three ways: referral by representation, advancement from the Acting for Sitcoms Class, or multiple film or network/cable television [[IMDB]] credits.<ref>Rohrbacher, Gunnar. "Classes - Actors Comedy Studio." ''Actors Comedy Studio''. Gunnar Rohrbacher, 17 Jan. 2011. Web. 29 Apr. 2015. <http://www.actorscomedystudio.com/classes/>.</ref>
==Celebrity Instructors== Actors Comedy Studios employs a variety of noted actors and casting directors as full-time and part-time faculty members. [[Elaine Hendrix]] ([[Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll (TV series)|Sex & Drugs & Rock & Roll]], [[The Parent Trap (1998 film)|The Parent Trap]], [[Romy and Michele's High School Reunion]]) is a resident ACS faculty member.<ref>"Elaine Hendrix - Actors Comedy Studio." Actors Comedy Studio. Gunnar Rohrbacher, 17 Feb. 2012. Web. 30 Apr. 2015. <http://www.actorscomedystudio.com/elaine-hendrix/>.</ref>
==Awards and recognition== Co-owner Gunnar Todd Rohrbacher and Actors Comedy Studio have been repeatedly recognized for their work by the Readers Choice Awards by Backstage West. In 2011, Gunnar was Runner-Up for '[http://www.backstage.com/news/readers-choice/carolyne-barry/ Favorite On-Camera Teacher]', '[http://www.backstage.com/news/readers-choice/gerry-katzman/ Favorite Comedy Teacher]', and '[http://www.backstage.com/news/readers-choice/holly-powell/ Favorite Audition Technique Teacher']. Actors Comedy Studio was recently voted by [[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]] as one of the top "9 Great Places to Study Comedy in Los Angeles."<ref name=":0">Wright, KC. "9 Places to Study Comedy in Los Angeles." ''Backstage West''. Backstage West, 13 Jan. 2015. Web. 30 Apr. 2015. <http://www.backstage.com/news/9-places-study-comedy-los-angeles/>.</ref>
Gunnar was interviewed by Press Pass LA, an entertainment news source covering celebrity news, red carpet events, and up & coming talent. The interview focused on the growth of Actors Comedy Studio, the rise of sitcoms in television, and refinement techniques implemented in their class structure.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.presspassla.com/inside-noise-show-inside-actors-comedy-studio/|title = THE INSIDE NOISE SHOW, INSIDE THE ACTOR'S COMEDY STUDIO|date = March 27, 2014|accessdate = June 3, 2015|website = PressPass LA|publisher = |last = Carpenter|first = Chrissy}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}}
==External links== * [http://www.actorscomedystudio.com Actors Comedy Studio]
[[Category:Organizations based in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Education in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Performing arts education in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{for|the fictional character in the New Zealand soap opera Shortland Street|Alison Piper}}
'''Alice Piper''' (7 June 1908 – 22 August 1985) was a [[Northern Paiute|Paiute]] (Nuwuvi) girl residing in [[Big Pine, California|Big Pine]], [[California]] who petitioned to attend the newly built Big Pine High School in 1923 and was denied entry due to her race.<ref>{{cite web |last=Murphy |first=Deb |url=http://www.inyoregister.com/node/5634 |title=Honoring Alice Piper |publisher=The Inyo Register |date=2014-02-14 |accessdate=2014-05-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524030953/http://www.inyoregister.com/node/5634 |archive-date=2014-05-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> At that time, California educational law prohibited Native American children from attending a public school if a separate government run Indian school was established within three miles of the public school.<ref name="berkeley">{{cite web|url=http://scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3936&context=californialawreview|title=scholarship.law.berkeley.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=3936&context=californialawreview|publisher=scholarship.law.berkeley.edu|accessdate=2014-05-31}}</ref>
Alice Piper along with six other Indian children sued the district for the right to attend. Piper sued on the grounds that her 14th Amendment rights had been violated knowing full well that she was not receiving the same education that the newly built public school afforded. The local Indian day school only offered education up to the 5th grade level, was underfunded, and lacked many basic resources. Furthermore, the District trustees had previously agreed to allow Indian students to attend the school if their parents voted for a measure that would fund the construction of the school. Although the measure passed, the board of trustees did not honor their agreement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/op.php?isbn=9780520037281 |title=Out Of Print : All Deliberate Speed : Charles M. Wollenberg - University of California Press |publisher=Ucpress.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-05-23}}</ref>
As a local resident recalled, "It was an exciting morning when the request was made, all the mothers and fathers of children of school age, Indian and white, were on the street to hear the answer of the district trustees. When the request was denied, the Indians immediately took court action pressing their case in the name of Alice Piper, a beautiful, intelligent, Indian girl." <ref name="Inyo Independent. May 10, 1946">Inyo Independent. May 10, 1946.</ref> The California Supreme Court unanimously ruled in her favor in the case [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720080122/http://sshl.ucsd.edu/brown/Piper.htm ''Piper v. Big Pine''] (1924), thus opening the door for herself and other Native American children to attend public schools in the state of California.<ref>{{cite web|author=' + auElement.html() + ' |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2014/02/13/native-girl-who-challenged-educational-boundaries-be-honored-153367 |title=Native Girl Who Challenged Educational Boundaries to Be Honored - ICTMN.com |publisher=Indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com |date=2014-02-13 |accessdate=2014-05-19}}</ref>
==Legacy== Piper's court victory became a turning point in the struggle for Native American education and ended the practice of sending Indian children who qualified for public school to separate government-run Indian day schools. ''Piper v. Big Pine'' was later cited by [[Chief Justice Warren]] as a precedent in the [[Brown v. Board of Education]] (1954) ruling that ended the practice of [[Segregation in the United States|segregated schools]] in the United States.<ref>Blalock-Moore, Nicole. [http://www.nicole-renee.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Blalock-Moore-2012-Piper-v.-Big-Pine-School-District-of-Inyo-County-Indigenous-Schooling-and-Resistance-in-the-Early-Twentieth-Century.pdf Piper v. Big Pine School District of Inyo County: Indigenous Schooling and Resistance in the Early Twentieth Century] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531182610/http://www.nicole-renee.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/Blalock-Moore-2012-Piper-v.-Big-Pine-School-District-of-Inyo-County-Indigenous-Schooling-and-Resistance-in-the-Early-Twentieth-Century.pdf |date=2014-05-31 }}.</ref>
Alice Piper stands as an early [[civil rights]] hero who championed equal educational opportunities for Native Americans, opening the door for equal access to education for all children regardless of race. Says Ada Wardle Robinson, the Inyo County Superintendent who held the office years after the Piper case decision had been handed down, "And as each year as both eighth grade and high school students graduate, we are reminded that the development of our youthful citizens is not confined to the white race and we are thankful to those Indians who years ago insisted that their children be given an equal chance."<ref name="Inyo Independent. May 10, 1946"/>
In 2009, the Big Pine Paiute Tribe and Big Pine Unified School District agreed to commemorate Piper's victory with a statue placed in front of the school in her honor. The statue was dedicated on June 2, 2014, on the 90th anniversary of Alice Piper's victory in front of the school steps on the same ground in which the board of trustees had denied Alice Piper the right to attend in 1923.<ref>{{cite web |last=Murphy |first=Deb |url=http://www.inyoregister.com/node/5708 |title=Community comes together to support Alice Piper project |publisher=The Inyo Register |date=2014-03-07 |accessdate=2014-05-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140520004454/http://www.inyoregister.com/node/5708 |archive-date=2014-05-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=James |first=Charles |url=http://www.inyoregister.com/node/6017 |title=Long Awaited Honor Comes to Big Pine Schools |publisher=The Inyo Register |date=2014-06-06 |accessdate=2014-06-12 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140613182855/http://www.inyoregister.com/node/6017 |archive-date=2014-06-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> This date also marks the day in 1924 that president Grover Cleveland signed the ''[[Indian Citizenship Act]]'', which declared all Indians, regardless of membership in a tribe, citizens of the United States.
As of 2014, 56% of the students who attend Big Pine high school are Native American. [[File:AlicePiperCropped.jpg|thumb|Alice Piper, (~age 15). Cropped from a larger picture showing a group of Big Pine Paiutes standing in front of the Paiute Community Center, c. early 1920s]] [[File:Big Pine Indian Camp Community Center.jpg|thumb|Big Pine Indian Camp Community Center]]
== References ==
{{reflist}}

|Hide header= |Ship country=[[Peru]] |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|Peru|naval}} |Ship name= ''Unión'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= 23 December 2010 |Ship builder=[[SIMA]], Callao, Peru |Ship laid down= 8 December 2012<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archivo.elcomercio.pe/politica/gobierno/infografia-asi-buque-escuela-que-construye-peru-noticia-1507529|title=Infografía: así será el buque escuela que construye el Perú|publisher=elcomercio.pe|date=December 9, 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref> |Ship launched= 22 December 2014<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.janes.com/article/57444/peruvian-navy-set-to-receive-bap-un|title=Peruvian Navy set to receive BAP {{sic|nolink=y|Union}}|publisher=janes.com (cache) |date=January 24, 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126084952/http://www.janes.com/article/57444/peruvian-navy-set-to-receive-bap-union|archivedate=January 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite Unión|publisher=navaltoday.com|date=January 31, 2016}}</ref> |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship identification= *{{MMSI Number|760105000}} *[[Maritime call sign|Callsign]]: OBAA |Ship honours= |Ship fate= |Ship status= In active service |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=[[Barque]] |Ship displacement= 3,200 t<ref name="specifications"/><ref name="tonne">{{cite news|url=http://www.janes.com/article/57575/peru-commissions-training-sail-ship-as-local-naval-shipbuilding-progresses|title=Peru commissions training sail ship as local naval shipbuilding progresses|publisher=janes.com (cache) |date=January 28, 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130085425/http://www.janes.com/article/57575/peru-commissions-training-sail-ship-as-local-naval-shipbuilding-progresses|archivedate=January 30, 2016}}</ref> |Ship length= {{convert|115.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref name="specifications">{{cite news|url=http://www.naval-technology.com/news/newsperuvian-navy-commissions-new-training-ship-4797853|title=Peruvian Navy commissions new training ship|publisher=naval-technology.com|date=February 1, 2016}}</ref><ref name="length"/><ref name="Sima characteristics"/> |Ship beam= {{convert|13.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}}<ref name="Sima characteristics"/> |Ship draft= {{convert|6.5|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion= Caterpillar 3516H engine,<ref name="data"/> a BERG propeller, a Rolls Royce maneuvering propeller and a Reintjes LAF-863L gearbox |Ship speed= {{convert|12|kn|kph|lk=in}}<ref name="speed">{{cite news|url=https://www.marina.mil.pe/noticias/3410|title=Defense minister oversaw the latest advances in the construction of Sailing Ship "Unión"|publisher=marina.mil.pe (cache) |date=January 28, 2016|language=Spanish|deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130085425/http://www.janes.com/article/57575/peru-commissions-training-sail-ship-as-local-naval-shipbuilding-progresses|archivedate=January 30, 2016}}</ref> |Ship range= |Ship complement= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= |Ship armor= |Ship aircraft= |Ship aircraft facilities= |Ship notes= |Ship sail plan= Four-masted barque; 34 sails, total sail area of 3,402 m² (36,620 sq. ft.)<ref name="sail">{{cite news|url=https://www.sailonboard.com/vessel/union/|title="Unión"|publisher=sailonboard.com|date=June 12, 2017}}</ref> }} |}
'''BAP ''Unión''''' is a [[training ship]] of the [[Peruvian Navy]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.janes.com/article/46823/peru-continues-to-rejuvenate-its-naval-capability|title=Peru continues to rejuvenate its naval capability|publisher=janes.com (cache)|date=December 8, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429095441/http://www.janes.com/article/46823/peru-continues-to-rejuvenate-its-naval-capability|archivedate=April 29, 2015|df=}}</ref> built between 2012–2015 by Shipyard Marine Industrial Services of Peru, known as [[SIMA]].<ref name="Navy Grau">{{cite news|url=http://www.livinginperu.com/the-peruvian-navy-takes-charge-107745/|title=The Peruvian Navy takes charge |publisher=peruthisweek.com|date=October 5, 2015}}</ref> It is a four-masted, steel-[[hull (watercraft)|hulled]], class "A" [[barque]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sailtraininginternational.org/vessels/definition-of-a-tall-ship|title=Definition of a Tall Ship|publisher=Sail Training International}}</ref> composed of 38 steel modules.<ref name="Sima characteristics">{{cite news|url=http://www.sima.com.pe/transparencia/mapafonafesp/3200_SimaPer%C3%BA_II_Memoria_Anual_2016.pdf|title=Memoria Anual 2016|publisher=sima.com.pe|date=December 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref> It has a total length (including [[bowsprit]]) of {{convert|115.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}};<ref name="specifications"/><ref name="length"/><ref name="Sima characteristics"/> a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|13.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}};<ref name="Sima characteristics"/> a [[Draft (nautical)|draft]] of {{convert|6.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}}; an [[air draft]] of {{convert|53.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}}; a [[Displacement (ship)|displacement]] of 3,200 [[metric tonne]]s;<ref name="specifications"/><ref name="tonne"/> a speed of {{convert|12|kn|kph|lk=in}} and a crew of 250 officers and trainees.<ref name="Sima characteristics"/> The ship's name honors<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.efe.com/efe/english/portada/latin-america-s-largest-sail-training-ship-docks-in-puerto-rico/50000260-3031052|title=Latin America's largest sail training ship docks in Puerto Rico|publisher=efe.com|date=September 4, 2016}}</ref> a Peruvian [[corvette]] that took part in the first stage of the 1879–1883 [[Naval Campaign of the War of the Pacific|War of the Pacific]] as part of a naval squadron under the command of [[Miguel Grau]], a hero of the Peruvian Navy.<ref name="Grau Hero">{{cite news|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/agencia/noticia-peru-pays-tribute-to-hero-miguel-grau-and-battle-of-angamos-477628.aspx|title=Peru pays tribute to hero Miguel Grau and Battle of Angamos|publisher=andina.com.pe|date=October 8, 2013}}</ref>
Like other similar ships, ''Unión'' has been conceived not only for training purposes, but also to be a sailing ambassador for its home country.<ref name="Sail ambassador">{{cite web|url=http://www.usil.edu.pe/en/news/usil-present-perus-first-travelling-embassy-peruvian-navys-bap-union-training-ship|title=USIL present on Peru’s first travelling embassy, the Peruvian Navy’s BAP Unión training ship|publisher=USIL|date=June 13, 2017}}</ref> Due to its features and dimensions, it has been considered (as of the date it was commissioned) the largest sail vessel in [[Latin America]].<ref name="length">{{cite news|url=http://www.latinpost.com/articles/112168/20160128/new-peruvian-training-ship-uni%C3%B3n-largest-of-its-kind-in-latin-america.htm|title=New Peruvian Training Ship Unión Largest of its Kind in Latin America|publisher=latinpost.com|date=January 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.peruthisweek.com/blogs-the-pride-of-the-peruvian-navy-the-bap-union-107058 |title=The Pride of the Peruvian Navy: The BAP Unión |publisher=peruthisweek.com (cache) |date=July 20, 2015 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150816034049/http://www.peruthisweek.com/blogs-the-pride-of-the-peruvian-navy-the-bap-union-107058 |archivedate=August 16, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://cimsec.org/latin-americas-training-vessels/25590|title=Latin America’s Training Vessels|publisher=cimsec.org|date=June 6, 2016}}</ref>
== History == [[File:BAP Unión en astillero SIMA.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Under construction in dry dock at [[SIMA]]]] For a long time, the [[Peruvian Navy]] desired a [[training ship]] for instruction of its cadets. Accordingly, the Peruvian government enacted 1985 Law N° 24094,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leyes.congreso.gob.pe/Documentos/Leyes/24094.pdf |title=Law N° 24094 |publisher=Peruvian Congress |date=February 8, 1985 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304075338/http://www.leyes.congreso.gob.pe/Documentos/Leyes/24094.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> which declared as a public necessity the navy having this kind of ship. However, due to the economic [[Economy of Peru#The 1980s|crisis]] of debt and hyper-inflation Peru suffered at the end of the 1980s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://international.ucla.edu/institute/article/19898|title=Peru's Debt Crisis and Subsequent Shock Economy|publisher=UCLA International Institute|date=February 4, 2005}}</ref> and later for public spending restraints, the project was postponed.
Eventually, in 2010 the project was approved and the construction was authorized.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gacetamarinera.com.ar/nota.asp?idNota=8157|title=La Marina de Guerra del Perú realizó la botadura del buque escuela a vela BAP "Unión"|archive-url=https://archive.is/20160128165436/http://www.gacetamarinera.com.ar/nota.asp?idNota=8157|publisher=gacetamarinera.com.ar|language=Spanish|dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 28, 2016|date=July 1, 2015}}</ref> In 2012 the Peruvian government announced its decision to order the ship's construction to the Shipyard Marine Industrial Services of Peru, known as [[SIMA]]; in cooperation with the Government of Spain,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archivo.larepublica.pe/12-11-2012/gobierno-espanol-cooperara-con-peru-en-construccion-de-buque-escuela|title=Government of Spain will cooperate in Peruvian training ship construction|publisher=larepublica.pe (cache) |date=November 12, 2012|language=Spanish|deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412182214/http://www.larepublica.pe/12-11-2012/gobierno-espanol-cooperara-con-peru-en-construccion-de-buque-escuela|archivedate=April 12, 2013}}</ref> through the contractors Cypsa Ingenieros Navales and [[Navantia]], which were responsible for the ship´s structural design.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/noticia/vigo/2013/11/07/empresa-vigo-disena-mayor-buque-escuela-mundo/0003_201311V7C1995.htm|title=Empresa de vigo diseña mayor buque escuela |publisher=lavozdegalicia.es|date=November 7, 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cypsa.com.es/eng/index.html|title=Cypsa Ingenieros Navales |publisher=cypsa.com.es|date=July 17, 2017}}</ref> The governmente named the ship as ''Union'' to honors a Peruvian [[corvette]] that took part in the first stage of the 1879–1883 [[Naval Campaign of the War of the Pacific|War of the Pacific]] as part of a naval squadron under the command of [[Miguel Grau]], a hero of the Peruvian Navy.<ref name="Grau Hero"/> On December 8, 2012 ''Unión''{{'}}s construction began with a [[keel laying]] ceremony in the presence of Peruvian president [[Ollanta Humala]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://diariocorreo.pe/politica/humala-justifica-retraso-a-ceremonia-por-med-203944/|title=Humala justifica retraso a ceremonia por medidas que va a tomar |publisher=diariocorreo.pe|date=December 8, 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref> The [[Hull (watercraft)|hull]] was finished two years later and the ship was [[Ceremonial ship launching|launched]] on December 22, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://peru21.pe/politica/ollanta-humala-participo-lanzamiento-mar-buque-escuela-vela-union-2207394|title=Ollanta Humala participó en lanzamiento a mar de buque escuela a vela Unión |publisher=peru21.pe|date=December 23, 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In June 2015, the ship received its [[Mast (sailing)|masts]] and [[propeller]]; and the interior fitout began in charge of contractors Acopafi and MO Contract. Also, according to an agreement between SIMA and Navantia, the ship was provided with an "Integrated Control System Platform, Navigation and Communications".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.navantia.es/noticia.php?id_noti=347|title=Acuerdo de colaboración de NAVANTIA y el Astillero de la Marina de Guerra del Perú|publisher=navantia.es|date=January 22, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.defense-aerospace.com/articles-view/release/3/160460/navantia-teams-with-peru-shipyard-for-naval-bids.html|title=Navantia Signs Partnership Agreement with Navy of Peru Shipyard|publisher=defense-aerospace.com|date=January 22, 2015}}</ref> [[File:Afirmado del Pabellón Nacional del Buque a Escuela a Vela “Unión” (24031453194).jpg|thumb|Commissioning ceremony]]
While the ship was under construction, the Peruvian government arranged training for the future ''Unión''{{'}}s crew with the help of an instructor from the [[Spanish Navy]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.infodefensa.com/latam/2015/07/23/noticia-relevo-instructor-cargo-entrenamiento-tripulacion-buque-escuela-marina.html|title=España completa entrenamiento de la primera tripulación de buque escuela del Peru|publisher=infodefensa.com|date=July 23, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> and by sending personnel to serve on training ships of other countries, such as the Mexican sailing ship {{ship|ARM|Cuauhtémoc|BE01|6}}.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/agencia/noticia-buque-escuela-mexicano-adiestra-a-oficiales-de-armada-peruana-563302.aspx|title=Buque escuela mexicano adiestra a oficiales de armada peruana|publisher=andina.com.pe|date=June 30, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> Also, a Peruvian delegation was sent to take part in maintenance and repair works on Colombian sailing ship {{ship|ARC|Gloria}}.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.infodefensa.com/latam/2015/01/27/noticia-militares-instruyen-colombia-mantenimiento-buques-escuela.html|title=Militares del Perú se instruyen en Colombia en el mantenimiento de buques a vela|publisher=andina.com.pe|date=January 27, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>
On January 27, 2016 BAP ''Unión'' was [[Ship commissioning|commissioned]] in an official flag raising ceremony held on its deck witnessed by the President Ollanta Humala, Jakke Valakivi, the Minister of Defense and Admiral Edmundo Deville, the Commander of the Navy.<ref name="commission"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.defensa.com/frontend/defensa/marina-guerra-peru-incorpora-oficialmente-buque-escuela-vela-bap-vn17657-vst336|title=The Navy of Peru officially incorporates Sailing Ship BAP {{sic|nolink=y|Union}}|publisher=defensa.com|date=January 21, 2016}}</ref> Captain Gianfranco Polar Figari was named to be the first captain of the ship, who conducted the [[sea trial]]s of the vessel in June 2016.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.infodefensa.com/latam/2016/06/22/noticia-buque-escuela-armada-sometido-pruebas.html|title=Peruvian Navy training ship undergoes its sea tests|publisher=infodefensa.com|date=June 22, 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
BAP ''Unión''{{'}}s first training cruise abroad began on July 27, 2016.<ref name="First trip">{{cite news|url=http://www.peruviantimes.com/28/navy-training-ship-union-sets-sail-from-callao/27151/|title=Navy Training Ship "Union" Sets Sail from Callao|publisher=peruviantimes.com|date=July 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://cimsec.org/rise-latin-american-shipyard/27386|title=The rise of the Latin American Shipyard|publisher=cimsec.org.com|date=August 22, 2016}}</ref> The set sailing ceremony was attended by Pedro Cateriano, the President of the Council of Ministers, Jakke Valakivi, the Minister of Defense, Ana María Sanchez, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Admiral Edmundo Deville, the Commander of the Navy, among other authorities.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.defensa.com/peru/bap-union-marina-guerra-peru-zarpa-primera-travesia|title=El BAP Union de la Marina de Guerra del Perú zarpa en su primera travesía|publisher=defensa.com|date=July 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
== Characteristics == [[File:BAP Unión (Callao).jpg|thumb|200px|right|BAP ''Unión'' in Callao, Perú]] [[File:Mascarón de proa BAP Unión.JPG|thumb|200px|right|Figurehead]] [[File:B.A.P. Union in Hamburg am 4. August 2017 (10).jpg|thumb|200px|right|Escutcheon]]
Although the main purpose of ''Unión'' is to serve as a [[training ship]] for the Peruvian Navy, it has also been conceived to be a sailing ambassador for her home country.<ref name="Sail ambassador"/> Due to its features and dimensions, it has been considered (as of the date it was commissioned) the largest sail vessel in [[Latin America]].
=== Specifications === BAP ''Unión'' is a four-masted [[barque]] with a hull composed of 38 steel modules.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.marina.mil.pe/notas-de-prensa/213|title=Nota de Prensa Nro 086 – Bautizo y Lanzamiento BAP Unión|publisher=marina.mil.pe (cache) |date=December 22, 2014|language=Spanish|deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305033021/https://www.marina.mil.pe/notas-de-prensa/213|archivedate=March 5, 2016}}</ref> It has a total length (including [[bowsprit]]) of {{convert|115.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}};<ref name="specifications"/><ref name="length"/> a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|13.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}}; a [[Draft (nautical)|draft]] of {{convert|6.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}}; an [[air draft]] of {{convert|53.50|m|ftin|abbr=on}}; a [[Displacement (ship)|displacement]] of 3,200 [[metric tonne]]s;<ref name="specifications"/><ref name="tonne"/> a speed of {{convert|12|kn|kph|lk=in}}<ref name="speed"/> and a crew of 250 officers and trainees.<ref name="Sima characteristics"/>
The ship's propulsion is supported by a [[Diesel engine|diesel]] Caterpillar 3516H engine,<ref name="data">{{cite news|url=http://www.defensa.com/frontend/defensa/lanzamiento-buque-escuela-vela-union-marina-guerra-peru-vn14253-vst336|title=Launch of the Sailing Ship {{sic|nolink=y|"Union"}} of the Navy of Peru|publisher=defensa.com|date=December 23, 2014}}</ref> a BERG propeller, a Rolls Royce maneuvering propeller and a Reintjes LAF-863L gearbox.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hardcoconsulting.com/boletin-22-hardco-consulting-cierra-la-venta-transmisiones-reintjes-para-el-buque-escuela-la-union/|title=Boletin 22 – Hardco Consulting cierra la venta transmisiones Reintjess para el Buque Escuela Unión|publisher=hardcoconsulting.com|date=December 2, 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref> Its sail rig is composed of 34 sails from sailmaking company Wienecke, arranged in bowsprit mast (5), foresail mast (9), mainmast (9), mizzenmast (8) and jiggermast (3), with a total sail area of approximately {{convert|3,402|m2|abbr=on}}.<ref name="sail"/>
BAP ''Unión'' is also equipped with AZCUE pumps for different applications including: BT-IL45D4-F, BT-HM25D4, KL30S40, LN-VP-40-160, CA-50-3, CA-40-1, MO-11/20, MO-19/20.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hardcoconsulting.com/boletin-23-buque-escuela-la-union-estara-equipado-con-bombas-azcue/|title=Boletin 23 – Buque Escuela Union estará equipado con bombas azcue|publisher=hardcoconsulting.com|date=December 4, 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref>
=== Figurehead ===
The ship's [[Figurehead (object)|figurehead]] was made of bronze by the Peruvian sculptor Pilar Martínez Woodman, and it features several symbols of the [[Inca Empire|Inca culture]] that previously existed in what is now Peru. As the main element it shows the image of the [[Sapa Inca]] (emperor) [[Topa Inca Yupanqui|Tupac Yupanqui]], known as "The Shining", who appears with his right arm raised to the image of the Inca sun god [[Inti]]; and who is placed over a representation of the archeological artefact known the [[twelve-angled stone]]. The Sapa Inca wears a checkered cloth and a cape that depicts ocean waves. He also wears two [[cougar|puma]] heads (the puma was a sacred animal in Inca culture)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.machupicchu.org/religious_significance_in_machu_picchu.htm|title=Religious significance in Machu Picchu|website=www.machupicchu.org|publisher=PeruForLess|access-date=February 16, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lateinamerika-studien.at/content/lehrgang/lg_mader/lg_mader-473.html|title=La trilogía inca: El cóndor, el puma y la serpiente|website=www.lateinamerika-studien.at.pe|publisher=Lateinamerika-Studien Online|access-date=February 16, 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref> as knee guards. His head is adorned with the [[mascapaicha]] (the Inca crown); and the shield he holds has the image of two rhombuses that represent the Inca Empire, known as [[Inca Empire|Tawantinsuyu]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://larepublica.pe/turismo/personajes/734771-tupac-yupanqui-el-mascaron-de-proa-del-buque-escuela-vela-union|title=Túpac Yupanqui, el mascarón de proa del buque escuela vela Unión|publisher=larepublica.pe|date=January 19, 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sima.com.pe/noticia1.asp?tn=255|title=Visita del Premier y el Ministro de Defensa al Buque Escuela a Vela|publisher=sima.com.pe (cache) |date=January 26, 2016|language=Spanish|deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055336/http://www.sima.com.pe/noticia1.asp?tn=255|archivedate=March 4, 2016}}</ref>
===Escutcheon=== ''Unión''{{'}}s [[escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] depicts the ship sailing over the ocean with the motto ''Cudendum Character Nautarum'' ("forging sailors' character") written in [[Latin]] below. It also contains an image of the sky with representations of the constellations [[Ursa minor]] and [[Crux]]. Over the escutcheon is the image of a bright sun and the legend "Marina de Guerra del Perú" (Navy of Peru) and below the name and number of the ship.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://diariocorreo.pe/ciudad/marina-de-guerra-la-union-y-sus-marinos-vuelven-a-navegar-en-el-mar-de-grau-649428/|title=Marina de Guerra: La Unión y sus marinos vuelven a navegar en el Mar de Grau|publisher=diariocorreo.pe|date=January 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
=== Interior equipment for training === Due to its use as a training ship, ''Unión''{{'}}s interior includes an auditorium, a library, a computing platform and classrooms to instruct cadets in astronomic navigation; meteorology; oceanography; hydrography; and naval operations and maneuvers.<ref name="length"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/noticia-president-union-bap-confirms-peruvian-progress-on-navy-engineering-596227.aspx|title=President: {{sic|nolink=y|Union BAP}} confirms Peruvian progress on navy engineering|publisher=andina.com.pe|date=January 27, 2016}}</ref>
== Voyages and trophies == [[File:The sailing school ship B.A.B. Union of the Peruvian Navy in Hamburg.jpg|thumb|right|200px|In the [[Port of Hamburg]] on 3 August 2017]] [[File:Tripulación del BAP Unión.jpg|thumb|200px|right|''Unión''{{'}}s crew with Peruvian defense minister in November 2017]]
''Unión''{{'}}s first training cruise abroad was in July 2016.<ref name="First trip"/> The journey, which was officially named as "VIEX 2016", [[acronym]] in Spanish of "Viaje de Instrucción al Extranjero 2016" (Training Trip Abroad 2016), had a length of three months, in which the ''Unión'' crew visited the ports of Guayaquil (Ecuador), Cartagena (Colombia), San Juan (Puerto Rico), La Habana (Cuba), Miami (United States), Veracruz (Mexico) and Balboa (Panama), before to returning to its base in [[Callao]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2016/09/04/latin-america-largest-sail-training-ship-docks-in-puerto-rico/|title=Latin America's largest sail training ship docks in Puerto Rico|publisher=foxnews.com (cache)|date=September 4, 2016|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160909064843/http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2016/09/04/latin-america-largest-sail-training-ship-docks-in-puerto-rico/|archivedate=September 9, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article102481827.html|title=The Peruvian navy is here and glad to see us |publisher=miamiherald.com|date=September 17, 2016}}</ref> The crew and navy cadets received instruction in naval exercises and maneuvers, as well as showing people abroad several elements of Peruvian culture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.defensa.com/frontend/defensa/bap-union-marina-guerra-peru-zarpa-primera-travesia-vn19199-vst336|title=El BAP Unión de la Marina de Guerra del Perú zarpa en su primera travesía|publisher=defensa.com|date=July 27, 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In 2017 the Peruvian Navy organized the "VIEX 2017". As a part of this journey, ''Unión'' participated in Rendez-Vous 2017 Tall Ships Regatta, a series of races organized by [[Sail Training International]], where the vessel won the race from [[Boston]] to [[Charlottetown]] ([[Gulf of Saint Lawrence]]) in Canada.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sailonboard.com/blog/rdv-2017-guest-port-1/|title=The Rendez-Vous 2017 Tall Ships Regatta Guest Ports Programme: Spectacular Canada Day Celebrations with the Tall Ships|publisher=sailonboard.com|date=July 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sailtraininginternational.org/events/2017-canada-150-tall-ships-regatta/results/|title=The Rendez-Vous 2017 Tall Ships Regatta Race Results|publisher=sailtraininginternational.org|date=July 2, 2017}}</ref> In this regatta the ship covered more than {{convert|450|nmi|km|lk=in}}.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/noticia-perus-bap-union-wins-international-tall-ship-race-in-canada-672367.aspx|title=Peru's BAP Union wins international tall ship race in Canada|publisher=andina.com|date=January 25, 2017}}</ref> In July 2017 ''Unión'' docked in South Quay in [[Canary Wharf]], [[London]], on a trip to foster Anglo-Peruvian relations, the visit coinciding with Peru's national day on 28 July. The Peruvian Ambassador to the [[Court of St James's]] attended the vessel.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wharf.co.uk/news/local-news/peruvian-tall-ship-union-arrives-13379229|title=Peruvian tall ship Union arrives in South Quay for six days|publisher=wharf.co.uk|date=July 24, 2017}}</ref>
In 2018 ''Unión'' participated in the event "Velas Latinoamérica 2018" (Sails Latin America), an international sailing regatta held every four years for ships from some Latin American countries. As part of this, the vessel visited several ports including Valparaiso, Guayaquil, Balboa, Curazao, Cartagena and Veracruz.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tallshipsnetwork.com/series/velas-latinoamerica-2018/|title=Sailing Latin America 2018|publisher=tallshipsnetwork.com|date=March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.panamatoday.com/life-style/maritime-spirit-7-navies-latin-america-took-panamanian-streets-7280|title=The maritime spirit of 7 navies of Latin America took to Panamanian streets|publisher=panamatoday.com|date=July 8, 2018}}</ref>
==See also==
*[[List of large sailing vessels]] *[[List of tall ships]]
== References == {{Reflist|3}}
==External links== {{Commons category|BAP Unión (BEV-161)}}

revision.text:
The building of '''[[Ochroma pyramidale|balsa]]-wood bridges''' is very often used as an [[educational technology]]. It may be accompanied by a larger project involving varying areas of study.
Typically classes which would include a balsa wood bridge cover the subject areas of [[physics]], [[engineering]], [[static equilibrium]], or building trades, although it may be done independently of any of these subjects. Building a balsa wood bridge can be done after completing a section or unit covering a related topic or the process of design and building can be used to guide students to a better understanding of the desired subject area.
[[Image:Balsa Bridge2.JPG|thumb|right|Building balsa wood bridges as a part of a unit on [[statics]], structures, forces, or construction trades is used by teachers to make the learning environment hands-on and to give students a real-world example of material covered in class]]
==Requirements== Although there is great variety between different balsa wood bridge projects, students are in general trying to build a bridge that can withstand the greatest weight before it fails. Other restrictions are often applied, but these vary widely from one contest to another. Sample requirements include: *restricting the maximum [[mass]] of the [[bridge]] *requiring a minimum [[Span (architecture)|span]] *requiring a minimum height of the [[roadway]] *restricting the physical dimensions of the bridge *restricting the size of individual pieces of [[balsa]] wood *limiting the amount of glue or balsa wood that can be used *requiring a driveable roadway that allows passage of a vehicle of specified size *restricting the way pieces are placed on the bridge (for example no parallel joining pieces)
[[Image:BalsaBridge Break.jpg|thumb|right|A balsa bridge breaks after holding a [[mass]] of 89 pounds (40.4 kg). Note that the [[failure]] of the entire [[bridge]] was a result of the failure of just the [[roadway]].]]
==Testing== Bridges are usually tested by applying a downward force on the bridge. How and where the [[force]] is applied varies from one contest to the next. There are two common methods of applying the test force to the bridge: *By hanging a container (such as a [[trash can]]) from the bridge and loading known weights into the container until the bridge breaks. The tester could also slowly add water or sand to the container until the bridge breaks and then weigh the container, providing a more accurate way to find the breaking force. *By using a [[machine|mechanical]] or [[pneumatic]] testing device that pushes down on the bridge with increasing force until the bridge breaks. If such a testing device is used it is often equipped with a method of automatically gathering force data, such as a [[pressure sensor]] or [[load cell]] connected to a computer. This approach is more accurate at measuring bridges that have secondary structure that proves to be stronger than the primary structure. This method is also less damaging to the bridge, whose structure usually remains intact since the load is automatically relieved at failure.
Of the two, the hanging container method provides by far the greater dramatic effect. Testing with a pneumatic press or ram is often complete in matter of seconds. Exceptionally strong bridges may take up to thirty minutes to test as weight (a combination of steel weights and sand is often used) is added to the suspended container.<ref>[http://balsabridge.com Physics Balsa Bridge Building Contest]</ref>
==Scoring and Grading==
===Scoring=== There are two chief ways that balsa wood bridge competitions may be scored. One way is simply by measuring how much weight each bridge can support. The second way is by structural efficiency, often expressed as a strength to weight ratio. The weight-only method is most effective where competitors are all building from a specified set of materials and are expected to use all the available materials. The strength-to-weight method is better when competitors are expected to use their materials as efficiently as possible.
===Competitive Grading=== Competitive grading compares how well each bridge does against bridges built by other participants to determine a grade. The top scoring bridge is assigned a maximum numeric grade (say, 100%) while the lowest scoring bridge that still meets all basic specifications is assigned a minimum grade (say, 70%).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://staff.hartdistrict.org/glyle/projects/bridge_project/index.html |title=Canyon High School Balsa Bridge Competition |access-date=2008-05-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518070719/http://staff.hartdistrict.org/glyle/projects/bridge_project/index.html |archive-date=2008-05-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The method guarantee that some scores will be high even if the overall quality of bridges is low. Conversely, it also guarantees that some scores will be low, even in situations where all bridges are of high quality.
===Standards-Based Grading=== Standards-based grading sets certain standards that need to be met in order to earn a certain grade. An example of standards-based scoring would be to say that all bridges that hold 50 kg earn full credit; bridges that hold 25 kg earn half credit, and bridges that hold less than 10 kg earn no credit.
This method allows every bridge to potentially earn full credit if the standards are met. In situations where competition is weak, this method runs the risk of having many competitors receive no credit.
==See also== *[[Spaghetti bridge]] *[[Bridge]] *[[Balsa]] *[[Trusses]] *[[Statics]] *[[Physics]] *[[Civil Engineering]] *[[Problem Based Learning]]
==References== {{More footnotes|date=April 2008}} <references/> *Barron, B. J., Schwartz, D. L., Vye, N. J., Moore, A., Petrosino, A., Zech, L., ''et al.'' (1998). Doing with understanding: Lessons from research on problem- and project-based learning. The Journal of the Learning Sciences, 7, 271–311. *Dods, R. F. (1997). An action research study of the effectiveness of problem-based learning in promoting the acquisition and retention of knowledge. Journal for the Education of the Gifted, 20(4), 423–437. *Schneider, R. M., Krajcik, J., Marx, R., & Soloway, E. (2002). Performance of students in project-based science classrooms on a national measure of science achievement. Journal of Research in Science Teaching, 39(5), 410–422.
==External links== *[http://www.balsabridge.com BalsaBridge.com] Photos, records, tips from contest held annually since 1980 at Notre Dame Regional Secondary in Vancouver BC
{{DEFAULTSORT:Balsa Wood Bridge}} [[Category:Bridges]] [[Category:Engineering education]] [[Category:Physics education]] [[Category:Science education]] [[Category:Science demonstrations]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Barbara Robotham | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Barbara Joyce Robotham | birth_date = {{Birth date|1936|01|15|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Blackpool]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|2013|07|01|1936|01|15|df=yes}} | death_place = Blackpool, England | occupation = {{plainlist| *Opera singer ([[mezzo-soprano]]) *Voice teacher }} }} '''Barbara Joyce Robotham''' (15 January 1936 – 1 July 2013) was an English [[mezzo-soprano]] opera singer and concert soloist who later became a distinguished voice teacher at the [[Royal Northern College of Music]].
==Life and career== The daughter of a [[Fylde Coast]] heating engineer, Robotham was born and raised in [[Blackpool]] where she was educated at the [[Blackpool Aspire Academy|Collegiate School for Girls]]. She then studied singing at the [[Royal Manchester College of Music]] under Elsie Thurston. She won the college's Curtis Gold Medal and the Imperial League of Opera Prize and in 1961 the Silver Medal at the [[Geneva International Music Competition|Concours de Genève]]. Her early performances included Handel's ''[[Alcina]]'' in Lisbon, Brahms' [[Alto Rhapsody|''Rhapsodie'']] conducted by Malcolm Sargent at the [[BBC Proms]], Britten's ''[[Canticles (Britten)|Abraham and Isaac]]'' at Aldeburgh, the [[Verdi Requiem]], and the Angel in Elgar's ''[[The Dream of Gerontius]]''.<ref>[[BBC Proms]] Archive. [http://www.bbc.co.uk/proms/archive/search/1960s/1964/august-31/7569 Prom 32, 31 August 1964]. Retrieved 17 March 2015.</ref><ref>Smith, Charlotte (29 August 2013). [http://www.gramophone.co.uk/classical-music-news/obituary-barbara-robotham-mezzo-soprano-and-teacher "Obituary: Barbara Robotham, mezzo-soprano and teacher"]. ''[[Gramophone Magazine]]''. Retrieved 17 March 2015.</ref><ref name = "DT">''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' (28 August 2013). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/10271774/Barbara-Robotham.html "Barbara Robotham: Barbara Robotham, who has died aged 77, abandoned her own highly successful career as a mezzo-soprano to become a singing teacher of genius"]. Retrieved 17 March 2015.</ref><ref>''[[The Times]]'' (16 August 2013). [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/obituaries/article3843982.ece "Obituary: Barbara Robotham"]. Retrieved 17 March 2015 {{subscription}}.</ref>
In the early 1970s, after her election as an Honorary Fellow of the Royal Manchester College of Music and having sung in over 100 performances and broadcasts in the UK and Europe, Robotham turned to teaching which she considered her true vocation. In 1974 she became a voice professor at [[Lancaster University]], and in 1979 she joined the faculty of the [[Royal Northern College of Music]]. Amongst her students there were [[Amanda Roocroft]] and [[Sara Fulgoni]]. She retired from full-time teaching at the RNCM in 1999, but continued to give master-classes at the college up until her final illness.<ref>[[Michael Kennedy (music critic)|Kennedy, Michael]] (October 2013). [http://opera.archive.netcopy.co.uk/article/october-2013/48/obituary "Obituary: Barbara Robotham"]. ''[[Opera (magazine)|Opera]]''. Retrieved 16 March 2015.</ref>
Robotham was a long-time resident of [[Lytham St. Annes]] where she was the President of the Lytham St Annes Choral Society from 1989 until her death. Her last professional performance was as the mezzo-soprano soloist in the Verdi Requiem which she performed with the society in 1997 at [[Blackpool Grand Theatre]]. She died in [[Blackpool Victoria Hospital]] at the age of 77 survived by her husband Eric Waite whom she had married in 1958 and their son Jonathan Waite.<ref name = "DT" /><ref>''Lytham St Annes Express'' (4 July 2013). "Obituary: Waite (nee Robotham), Barbara Joyce".</ref><ref>Lytham St Annes Choral Society. [http://lytham-st-annes.org.uk/lsacs/concerts-past/9th-november-2013/ "Barbara Robotham 1936 – 2013"]. Retrieved 16 March 2015.</ref>
==Recordings== *'''''[[William Walton]]: Orb & sceptre, Te Deum, Crown Imperial''''' – Barbara Robotham (mezzo-soprano); Anthony Rolfe Johnson, (tenor); Brian Rayner Cook, (baritone); City of Birmington Symphony Orchestra and Chorus; [[Louis Frémaux]] (conductor). Recorded in 1977. Label: [[EMI]] *'''''[[Igor Stravinsky]]: Les Noces, Mass, Cantata''''' – The third item on this album, Stravinsky's [[Cantata (Stravinsky)|Cantata]] set to medieval English texts is performed by Barbara Robotham (mezzo-soprano); Gerald English (tenor); Prague Philharmonic Chorus; Czech Philharmonic Orchestra; [[Karel Ancerl]] (conductor. Recorded in 1967. Label: [[Supraphon]]

{{Use British English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Barn the Spoon |image = Barn the Spoon Portrait.jpg |image_upright = |caption = Barn the Spoon |birth_name = Barnaby Alexander Carder |birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1982}} |birth_place = |residence = London |nationality = British |occupation = Artist, spoon carver, author |website = [https://barnthespoon.com/ barnthespoon.com]
}} '''Barnaby Alexander Carder''', known as '''Barn the Spoon''' (born 1982), is a British [[artisan]] [[spoon]] carver, teacher, author and co-founder of Spoonfest, the annual international festival of spoon carving in [[Edale]] in Derbyshire, UK.{{cite web|title=Woodsmen Barnaby Carder|url=http://www.elledecoration.co.uk/news/spoonfest/ |website=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]|publisher=Hearst Magazines UK|accessdate=21 February 2017}} He is also founder of the Green Wood Guild, a collective of [[green wood]] carvers who run carving workshops and owns a spoon shop and woodworking venue in Hackney in London's [[East End]]. Carder also teaches spoon carving, [[woodworking]] and [[bladesmithing]] (with master [[Blacksmith|smith]] Nic Westermann).{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Jonny|title=How an axe-forging workshop brought out my inner craftsman|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/11665716/How-an-axe-forging-workshop-brought-out-my-inner-craftsman.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=22 April 2017}} ==Early life and education== Carder was born in 1982 and grew up in [[Berkshire]].{{cite web|last1=Ranscombe|first1=Siân|title=Barnaby Carder, the British spoon-carver|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/10892365/Barnaby-Carder-the-British-spoon-carver.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=15 April 2017}} At the age of 12 a neighbour introduced him to [[woodturning]] by showing him how to make bowls{{cite web|title=Barn the Spoon, Spoon Carver|url=http://spitalfieldslife.com/2012/11/13/barn-the-spoon-spoon-carver/|website=Spitalfields Life|accessdate=22 April 2017}} and soon he had a [[lathe]] in the garage of his parents' house.{{cite web|title=The Spoon Carving Enthusiast|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p04d0nzz|website=BBC World Service|accessdate=22 April 2017}} He graduated from Bristol University with a degree in biology, intending initially to become a biology teacher before becoming apprenticed to a cabinet maker.{{cite web|title=Barnaby Carder – The Spoon Whittler|url=http://www.woodworkersinstitute.com/news/2013/05/barnaby-carder-the-spoon-whittler/|website=Woodworkers Institute|publisher=GMC Publications LTD.|accessdate=22 February 2017}} After apprenticing himself to green wood worker Mike Abbott in [[Hereford]], he then spent 3 years working in forestry and living in the forests, sourcing [[green wood]]. It was while living in the woods he began to carve and then sell spoons for a living travelling between Oxford and Bristol,{{cite web|last1=Galliver|first1=John|title=The man who makes his living whittling wooden spoons|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22467510|website=BBC News|accessdate=22 April 2017}} finding that the spoons sold better in cities. Carder holds an official [[Peddler#Legislation and regulation|pedlar's licence]] for this purpose. ==Spoons and green wood carving== Carder is founder of The Green Wood Guild, London's school of traditional woodwork, based at [[Stepney City Farm]].{{cite web|title=Wood|url=http://stepneycityfarm.org/rural-arts/wood/?doing_wp_cron=1487722612.2000598907470703125000|website=Stepney City Farm|accessdate=22 February 2017}} The Guild also has a woodworking venue at [[Abney Park]] in Stoke Newington. The guild provides courses in woodworking, carving, whittling and bladesmithing and runs two regular clubs, Whittlers Anonymous and Spoonclub. Carder uses freshly cut (green) wood and traditional techniques to carve his spoons, usually using an axe, spoon knife (a curved bladed knife for hollowing out the bowl of the spoon), and small carving knife. The wood is sourced locally from parks in and around London and is recycled from trees which have been removed for conservation reasons.{{cite web|last1=Chia|first1=Jessica|title=Barnaby Carder carves his spoons at shop-front door|url=http://www.eastlondonlines.co.uk/2014/09/barnaby-carder-carves-spoons-in-shop-front/|website=East London Lines|accessdate=3 May 2017}} Carder states that a single spoon can take him from twenty minutes to two hours to carve. He opened his Hackney Road shop at the end of 2012 and carves in the shop window, where people often stop to watch. Carder has a display of some of his spoons in the [[Fuller Craft Museum]] in [[Brockton, Massachusetts]]{{cite web|last1=Knox|first1=Robert|title=Time for John Singer Sargent at Duxbury museum|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/regionals/south/2017/04/07/time-for-john-singer-sargent-duxbury-museum/eFN31tkEAmrLvpFiLPWKaM/story.html|website=Boston Globe|accessdate=22 April 2017}} and his spoons have also sold in the Conran shop in Tokyo.{{cite web|last1=Tassell|first1=Tony|title=FT Masterclass: spoon carving with Barnaby Carder|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ee980e4ch-5379-11e6-9664-e0bdc13c3bef|website=Financial Times|accessdate=14 April 2017}} In 2016 Carder and Robin Wood joined [[Stevie Parle]] during [[London Craft Week]] to explore wood-fired cooking and how dining from wooden utensils can affect the experience of eating.{{cite web|last1=Howells|first1=Tom|title=See the wood for the trees: Robin Wood and Barn the Spoon do dinner at Craft|url=http://www.wallpaper.com/design/seeing-the-wood-for-the-trees-robin-wood-and-barn-the-spoon-set-up-shop-at-craft|website=Wallpaper|publisher=Time Inc.|accessdate=22 April 2017}} Carder has been described by the press as "legendary"{{cite web|last1=Frizzell|first1=Nell|title=The best craft festivals around the country|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/apr/09/knitting-skills-knitwear-faroe-islands-festival-sweaters-knit|website=The Guardian|accessdate=22 April 2017}} and it has been said that "No one in Britain knows more about crafting a spoon from green wood than Barn the Spoon". In May 2017 following the release of his book, Carder announced the lease on his shop is to expire and he hopes to leave London to be closer to nature. He launched a '1000 spoons' project where he intends to carve 1000 spoons from a single tree, using any profits to plant and maintain his own woodland.{{cite web|last1=Cooper|first1=Jonny|title=Carving out a new life as a spoon whittler|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health-fitness/mind/carving-new-life-spoon-whittler/|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=16 June 2017}} ==Teaching== Carder teaches spoon and bowl carving at his shop on the Hackney Road and has run courses at various other venues around the UK including [[Stepney City Farm]], [[Tate Britain]], the [[Pitt Rivers Museum]]{{cite web|title=Spring 2016|url=https://www.prm.ox.ac.uk/sites/default/files/uploads/F%20of%20PRM%2085%20Spring%202016%20LR%20for%20WEB%20AWARD%20FC.pdf|website=The Friends of the Pitt Rivers Museum, Oxford Magazine|accessdate=22 April 2017}} and [[Heal's]].{{cite web|title=Make it|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/whats-on/tate-britain/courses-and-workshops/make-it-knife-carving-workshop|website=Tate Britain|accessdate=22 February 2017}}{{cite web|title=Barnaby Carder Spatula Carving Workshop|url=https://www.heals.com/barnaby-carder-2.html|website=Heals|accessdate=22 April 2017}} In May 2017 Carder published his first book, a spoon carving guide entitled ''Spon: A Guide to Spoon Carving and the New Wood Culture'' published by [[Penguin Books]].{{cite web|title=Spon A Guide to Spoon Carving and the New Wood Culture|url=https://www.penguin.co.uk/books/1112684/spon/9780753545973/|website=Penguin books|accessdate=13 March 2017}} 'Spon' refers to the [[Old English|Anglo-Saxon English]] word for a wood chip which is believed to be the [[etymology|etymological]] root of spoon. In it Carder shows techniques and the appropriate use of tools used in creating different types of spoon.{{cite book|last1=The Spoon|first1=Barn|title=Spon: A Guide to Spoon Carving and the New Wood Culture|date=2017|publisher=Penguin (Virgin Books)|isbn=0753545977}} Carder explains the need to think in three dimensions, as with other forms of sculpture, and has said {{Cquote|Perfection is always just a spoon away.{{cite web|last1=Henley|first1=Jon|title=Carve your own spoon|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/feb/06/carve-your-own-spoon|website=The Guardian|accessdate=22 April 2017}}}} ==Spoonfest== [[File:Spoonfest banner.jpg|thumb|Banner entrance to Spoonfest]] Carder is co-founder of Spoonfest with Robin Wood MBE (trustee and ex-chairman of the [[Heritage Crafts Association]]).{{cite web|last1=Wallis Simons|first1=Jake|title=The joys of whittling|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/lifestyle/9796481/The-joys-of-whittling.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=14 April 2017}}{{cite web|title=Spoonfest|url=https://www.companiesintheuk.co.uk/ltd/spoonfest|website=Companies in the UK|accessdate=22 February 2017}} Spoonfest is an annual international festival of spoon carving held in [[Edale]], Derbyshire, which attracts around 300 people a year.{{cite web|last1=Fox|first1=Killian|title=What we love about food in 2017|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/ng-interactive/2017/feb/19/the-5th-annual-ofm-50-what-we-love-about-food-in-2017|website=The Observer|publisher=Guardian News and Media|accessdate=14 April 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Ventoso|first1=Luis|title=Relájate: talla cucharas de madera|url=http://www.abc.es/estilo/abci-relajate-talla-cucharas-madera-201704210958_noticia.html|website=ABC|accessdate=22 April 2017}} {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://vimeo.com/36075025 Barn the Spoon on Vimeo] *[http://benjaminbrookes.com/Barn-the-Spoon Dance of the Axe and Knife] *[https://vimeo.com/76502635 Spoonfest on Vimeo] {{Authority control}} [[Category:Alumni of the University of Bristol]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:British writers]] [[Category:British woodcarvers]] [[Category:Crafts educators]] [[Category:Festival founders]] [[Category:People from Berkshire]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2015}} {{inline|date=February 2015}}
The '''Bing Act''' of 1921 was an Ohio law, adopted April 29, 1921, that stated children between the ages of six and eighteen are required to attend school. There were two major exceptions to this law: a child who had already graduated high school did not have to stay in school until turning eighteen; and a child who was sixteen years old and had passed the seventh grade was allowed to work as a farmer instead of attending school.
The Bing Bill was drafted for Ohio legislation by Ohio Council of Child Welfare’s education committee. Although the Bill had many supporters, women’s groups were the primary activists for the bill. On January 24, 1921, the bill was introduced to the [[Ohio House of Representatives]] by [[Simeon H. Bing]] from [[Gallia County]], chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Schools and President of [[Rio Grande College]].
The Bing Bill was opposed by groups such and farmers and the Amish. They didn’t want to take their children out of the workforce and they knew it would cost them more with taxes being raised to run the schools. They also thought the schools would train the children to be delinquent and have bad behavior. Supporters argued that schooling will help the young farmers bring more efficient practices and modern ideas to the farms.
This law was created to stop [[child labor]]. Business wanted to employ children so that they could pay them less money than they would an adult worker. People who opposed child labor were for the Bing act because it mandated that children had to be at least sixteen years of age to work at most industries in Ohio. At age sixteen the children had to get a work permit from their parents and school to say they have passed the seventh grade and are allowed to work.
When children were forced to attend school some families had some financial troubles because they relied on their children to help with the bills and help on the farms. The schools also had financial trouble because more children attended schools. Every school had to have equivalent education through the highs school level and rural schools needed transportation. The [[Ohio Legislature]] adopted a 3 percent [[sales tax]] that gave half of the funds to the school districts for education purposes and [[operating costs]]. With making schooling mandatory, school attendance went up. This reduced illiteracy and promoted good citizenry. Businessmen and industrialists were for the Bing bill because they wanted more intelligence in the work field.
== References ==
{{reflist}}
*{{cite journal|last=Venkateswaran|first=Uma|title=The Bing Law and youth education policy: The administration of compulsory school laws in Cleveland, Ohio, 1910-1930|date=19 April 1990|pages=171–215|url=http://etd.ohiolink.edu/view.cgi?acc_num=case1054747433|accessdate=11 March 2013}} *"Bing Act of 1921", Ohio History Central, July 1, 2005, http://www.ohiohistorycentral.org/entry.php?rec=1506 *"Education", Patterson for Ohio House, 2000, https://web.archive.org/web/20120822013906/http://pattersonforohio.com/education/
[[Category:Education in Ohio]] [[Category:1921 in Ohio]] [[Category:Compulsory education]]

{{Infobox building | name = Schönburg | map_type = Germany | building_type = Castle | location = Saxony-Anhalt | location_country = Germany | coordinates = {{coord|51|9|43|N|11|52|11|E|type:landmark_region:DE-ST|display=inline,title}} }}
'''Schönburg Castle''' is in the municipality of Schönburg 4.5 kilometers east of [[Naumburg]] at the heart of [[Federal Republic of Germany]] in the State of [[Saxony-Anhalt]]. It has been proposed by Germany for inscription in the List of [[World Heritage]].
[[File:Schönburg Castle.jpg|thumb|Schönburg Castle in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany]]
== Location == The Late Romanesque ruins of Schönburg Castle are on top of a mottled sandstone cliff by the [[Saale]] River, which is 40 metres high and declines sharply in the west. The castle was built with the local mottled [[sandstone]].
== History == The castle on top of the southern slopes of the Saale was erected as the most important castle in the 12th century on commission by the [[bishops]] of Naumburg. The bishops owned several castles within their territory to secure their assets. From 1158 at the latest, a free [[noble family]] that owned property around [[Naumburg]] named itself after the castle. It was first documented in 1137. Schönburg has been preserved to this day and is an example from the time of classical [[castle]] construction.<ref>{{cite book|title=Zur Geschichte und Baugeschichte der Schönburg, Burgenlandkreis. ''In:'' Burgen und Schlösser in Sachsen-Anhalt 12.|trans-title=On the history of Schönburg, Burgenland. ''In:'' Castles and palaces in Saxony-Anhalt.|page=15-79|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Saxony-Anhalt|date=2003|language=German}}</ref>
== Architecture == All the walls, gates and parts of the [[Palas]] have retained their original substance from the High Middle Ages, as have parts of the interior like visible [[chimneys]] dated to 1220 and decorated windows. The [[architecture]] and decorations found here correspond to other monuments in the World Heritage nomination.<ref>{{cite book|title=Die Schönburg. Bischofsburg zu Naumburg. Die erste Neufassung der Geschichte der Schönburg seit 1936.|trans-title=Schönburg Castle. The castle of the Bishop of Naumburg. The amended version of the history of Schöburg since 1036.|page=15-79|author=Baumgart, Uwe|publisher=Naumburg|date=1997|language=German}}</ref>
== World Heritage Nomination == Schönburg Castle is one of the eleven components of the cultural landscape “[[Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut]]”. As a landmark the castle is an important part of the lines of sight connecting the [[cultural landscape]] as a whole.<ref group=note>The Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V. is the coordinating body for this nomination: http://www.naumburg-cathedral.de/.</ref> <ref name="Rössler">{{cite book|last=Rössler|first=Mechtild|title=Linking Nature and Culture: World Heritage Cultural Landscapes. |date=2002|publisher=Unesco Press}}</ref> The World Heritage nomination is representative for the processes that shaped the continent during the [[High Middle Ages]] between 1000 and 1300: [[Christianization]], the so-called “[[Landesausbau]]” and the dynamics of cultural exchange and transfer characteristic for this very period.<ref>UNESCO (2017): WHC/17/41.COM/INF.8B1.{{cite book|title=Nominations to the World Heritage List (Krakow, 2017).|publisher= UNESCO press|page=54|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com/|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Bartlett">{{cite book|last=Bartlett|first=Robert|title=The Making of Europe: Conquest, Colonization and Cultural Change 950-1350|date=1994|publisher=Penguin}}</ref>
==See also== * [[World Heritage Convention]] * [[World Heritage site]] * [[World Heritage Committee]] * [[High Middle Ages]] * [[Cultural landscape|Cultural Landscape]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Notes == {{reflist|30em|group=note}}
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6FPjj5cWWCg Video of the cultural landscape of Naumburg]
[[Category:Cultural heritage]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:High Middle Ages]] [[Category:Landscape]] [[Category:Saxony-Anhalt]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2014}}
{{Infobox school | name = Covenant Christian High School | native_name = | image = | alt = | caption = | motto = | location = 611 15th Street SW | city = [[DeMotte, Indiana|DeMotte]] | state = [[Indiana]] | county = [[Jasper County, Indiana|Jasper County]] | zipcode = 46310 | country = US | coordinates = {{coord|41.187578|-87.205166|type:edu|display=inline,title}} | established = | type = [[Private school]] | district = | grades = 9-12 | superintendent = | principal = Mike Laneve | enrollment = 110 | enrollment_as_of = 2013-2014 | faculty = 7 | team_name = Knights | conference = [[IHSAA Conference-Independent Schools|Independent]] | rivals = | newspaper = | colors = {{color box|#4169E1}} {{color box|white}} | website = [http://www.cchrhs.org/ Official website] | footnotes = }}
'''Covenant Christian High School''' is a [[private school|private]] [[Christian school|Christian]] high school located in [[DeMotte, Indiana]], United States.
==About== Covenant Christian opened in DeMotte in 1999. The school started with one ninth grade class. Initially 14 first-year (freshmen) students attended. In the three subsequent years, another grade level was added, so that by the fall of 2002, the school had freshman through senior students. In the spring of 2003 the first class graduated with 15 students, along with two exchange students who received recognition for their time at Covenant.<ref>"[http://www.cchrhs.org/history.cfm Mission Statement and School History]." Covenant Christian High School. Retrieved on December 26, 2012.</ref> Current enrollment now stands at about 110.
==Educational philosophy== The purpose of Covenant Christian is to educate students in such a way that each student will become a useful and creative citizen of Christ's Kingdom and of the student's community. Therefore, education includes a variety of academic, physical, spiritual, and service components.
==Academics==
* Each year, students take the ECA test as required by the State of Indiana. Test scores are consistently high. * All Indiana schools are assigned a letter grade (A thru F) based on student performance on standardized tests and their academic growth rate from year to year. CCHS has earned the rating "B" each academic year. 45 course offerings * 90% of students continue their education after high school, with over 75% attending college or university * [[ACT (test)|ACT Composite score]] - 24.0% since 1999; 23.9% in 2013<ref>"[http://www.cchrhs.org/CCHSFacts.cfm" CCHS Quick Facts] Covenant Christian High School. retrieved on April 2, 2014.</ref>
==Student development==
* A key component of student development takes place during "Service Week" each year. Students are given the opportunity to learn about their future life of service in God's Kingdom through various service opportunities.<ref>"[http://www.cchrhs.org/serviceprojects.cfm" CCHS Service Week] Covenant Christian High School. retrieved on April 2, 2014.</ref> * Each student is required to complete an additional 12 hours of [[community service]] during the school year.
==See also== {{Portal|Indiana|Schools}} * [[List of high schools in Indiana]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cchrhs.org/ Covenant Christian High School] * [https://www.facebook.com/DeMotteChristian/ Covenant Christian HS - Facebook]
[[Category:1999 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:Christian schools in Indiana]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1999]] [[Category:High schools in Indiana]] [[Category:Schools in Jasper County, Indiana]]
{{Edu-org-stub}}

page.title: Edmund S. Muskie Graduate Fellowship Program

revision.comment: add attribution for public domain material
revision.text:
'''Edmund S. Muskie Graduate Fellowship Program''' was a program of the [[Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs]] of the [[United States Department of State]] in 1992-2013.<ref name="embassy"/>
The Edmund S. Muskie Graduate Fellowship Program provided opportunities for graduate students and professionals from Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Russia, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine and Uzbekistan for one-year non-degree, one-year degree or two-year degree study in the United States.<ref name="embassy"/>
Eligible fields of study for the Muskie Program were business administration, economics, education, environmental management, international affairs, journalism and mass communication, law, library and information science, public administration, public health, and public policy.<ref name="embassy"/>
The program was established by the [[United States Congress]] beginning from 1992 [[Fiscal_year#United_States|fiscal year]] ({{USPL|102|138}}, Sec. 227) and was designated [[Edmund S. Muskie]] name by the [[Freedom Support Act]] of 1992 ({{USPL|102|511}}, Sec. 801).
Due to fiscal constraints<ref name="embassy">{{cite web|url=https://uz.usembassy.gov/education-culture/exchange-programs/edmund-s-muskie-graduate-fellowship-program/|title=Edmund S. Muskie Graduate Fellowship Program|publisher=Official website of the U.S. Embassy in Uzbekistan (uz.usembassy.gov)|access-date=2017-09-15}} {{PD-notice}}</ref> the Muskie program was discontinued in 2013 (the final cohort selected in 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tc.columbia.edu/cice/current-issue/07_Campbell.pdf|title=International Scholarship Graduates Influencing Social and Economic Development at Home: The Role of Alumni Networks in Georgia and Moldova|author=Anne C. Campbell|publisher=Current Issues in Comparative Education (CICE)|date=Fall 2016|format=pdf|access-date=2017-09-15}}</ref>).
In the past, the program was administered by [[International Research & Exchanges Board]] and [[American Council of Teachers of Russian|American Council of Teachers of Russian/American Council for Collaboration in Education and Language]].
In 2015 [[Edmund S. Muskie Internship Program]] was launched as a professional exchange program. It provides summer internship placements, career training, and financial support to Eurasian scholars and graduate students studying in the United States. The program is administered by [[Cultural Vistas]].
== Notable alumni == * [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] * [[Aliona Babak]] * [[Victoria Voytsitska]] * [[Alexander Kvitashvili]] * [[Lesya Orobets]] * [[Andriy Pyvovarsky]]
==See also== * [[Edmund S. Muskie|Edmund Muskie]] * [[Edmund S. Muskie Internship Program]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Scholarships in the United States]] [[Category:Higher education in the United States]]
{{US-gov-stub}}

[[Abu Dhabi]], capital of the [[United Arab Emirates]], is home to various international and local private [[school]]s and [[University|universities]], with teaching in several languages spoken by Abu Dhabi residents. These schools operate under the authority of the [[Abu Dhabi Education Council]] as well as the [[United Arab Emirates Ministry of Education]].
==List of educational institutions==
===Primary and secondary schools=== Various international schools are located in the [[Educational Zone]]. * [[ADNOC Schools]] * ABC Private School * Abu Dhabi Grammar School (Canada/Nova Scotia) * [[Abu Dhabi Indian School]] * Abu Dhabi International School * Al Manara School * [[Al Nahda National Schools]] * Al Noor Indian Islamic School * Al Najah Private School * Al Worood Academy * Al Raha International School * Amna Bint Wahab * Ashbal Al Quds Private School * Asian International Private School * [http://www.bedayatinursery.ae Bedayati Nursery] * Bright Kids Nursery * [[Brighton College#Additional information|Brighton College Abu Dhabi]]<ref>[http://brightoncollegeabudhabi.net Brighton College Abu Dhabi Home]</ref> * Canadian International School (CIS) * Emirates Private School * Emirates Future Internarional Academy<ref>{http://efiaschool.com/}</ref> * Giggles English School, Kindergarten & Nursery * Landus Public School * [[Lycée Louis Massignon (United Arab Emirates)|Lycée Louis Massignon]] (École Française) * [[American Community School of Abu Dhabi|The American Community School of Abu Dhabi]] * [[American International School - Abu Dhabi|The American International School in Abu Dhabi]] * Tabook * [[British International School, Abu Dhabi]] * [[The British School - Al Khubairat]] * The Cambridge High School * First Steps School Nursery * The German School Abu Dhabi * Indian Islahi Islamic School * International Academic School, Abu Dhabi * International Community School * [[International School of Choueifat, Abu Dhabi]] * [[Islamia English School]] * Our Own English High School * Pioneers International Private School * PISCO Private School * Philippine National School * [http://www.reachbritishschool.com Reach British School] * Sheikh Khalifa Bin Zayed Arab Pakistani School * [[Shaikh Khalifa Bin Zayed Bangladesh Islamia School]] * Sherwood Academy * [[St Joseph's School (Abu Dhabi)|St. Joseph's School]] * Noah's Ark Nursery * [http://www.tweetynursery.com Tweety Nursery - Abu Dhabi] * Little Flower (P) School * Umm Amar Secondary School * Wisdom High School * Sunrise English Private School * Institute of Applied Technology (IAT) * St Josephs High School Abu Dhabi * Merryland International
===Skill development institutes=== * [http://www.charteredcenter.com Chartered Institute of Finance and Management] * [http://www.arabexpertsinstitute.com Arab Experts Training Institute]
===Colleges and universities=== * [[Abu Dhabi University]] * Al Khawarizmi International College * European International College * [[Higher Colleges of Technology]] * [[Paris-Sorbonne University Abu Dhabi]] * [[INSEAD]] * [[Zayed University]] * [[Khalifa University]] * [[New York University Abu Dhabi]] * [[New York Institute of Technology]] * [[Masdar Institute of Science and Technology]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2007/abu-dhabi.html|title=MIT, Abu Dhabi Future Energy Company sign cooperative agreement|work=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|date=2007-02-26|accessdate=2007-05-30}}</ref> * [[Petroleum Institute]] * [[New York Film Academy]] * [[Al Ain University of Science and Technology]] * [[ALHOSN University]] * [[University of Strathclyde]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.strath.ae/|title=University of Strathclyde in the UAE|work=University of Strathclyde - Graduate School of Business|date=2009-03-17|accessdate=2009-03-17}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Abu Dhabi topics|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:Education in Abu Dhabi| ]] [[Category:Abu Dhabi]]
